docs.abstract: March dash by North Korean asylum seekers into Spanish Embassy, Beijing, while focusing attention on plight of North Korean refugees, has spurred ferocious Chinese crackdown; hundreds of thousands of North Korean refugees who remain illegally in China now face high level of scrutiny, detention and deportation; measures reflect China's effort to discourage further asylum seekers and placate North Korea; have shut down crucial source of food for North Korea's hard-hit northeastern provinces, since migrants frequently send food and money home; map; photo (M)

headline.main: North Koreans in China Now Live in Fear of Dragnet

docs.snippet: Since March, four North Korean teenage girls have not left the back room of Mr. Piao's low brick hovel here, for fear they will be caught and deported. They eat, sleep and pass long boring days crouched on an orange linoleum floor. The only visible s
docs.lead_paragraph: Since March, four North Korean teenage girls have not left the back room of Mr. Piao's low brick hovel here, for fear they will be caught and deported. They eat, sleep and pass long boring days crouched on an orange linoleum floor. The only visible sliver of the outside world is a crude ladder outside the back door. To protect them Mr. Piao, an ethnic Korean Chinese, has placed a fake padlock on the wooden front door and boarded up windows to make his shack appear deserted. But if the police knock, the girls will mount the ladder, scramble over a wall and disappear into the dark safety of the forested mountains.

docs.abstract: Authorities let 30 Internet cafes reopen, Beijing, month after deadly fire killed 25 people and led them to close all of city's Internet cafes; reopened cafes pledge to bar minors, follow fire codes, keep records of computer use and install software to filter out 'unhealthy' content (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: After Fire, Some Internet Cafes Reopen

docs.snippet: More than a month after a deadly fire in Beijing killed 25 people and led officials to close all the city's Internet cafes, the authorities have allowed 30 to reopen. Before the fire, an estimated 2,400 Web bars operated in the city, only 200 of them
docs.lead_paragraph: More than a month after a deadly fire in Beijing killed 25 people and led officials to close all the city's Internet cafes, the authorities have allowed 30 to reopen. Before the fire, an estimated 2,400 Web bars operated in the city, only 200 of them authorized. The 30 newly reopened ones made new pledges to bar minors, follow fire codes, keep records of computer use for 60 days and install software to filter out ''unhealthy'' content like pornography or politically subversive messages. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

docs.abstract: Chinese police quickly detain small group of North Korean refugees trying to hold protest outside foreign ministry (S)0

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: North Koreans' Protest Foiled

docs.snippet: A small number of North Korean refugees tried to hold a protest at the gates of the foreign ministry but were quickly detained by the police. Three people held up a small banner saying ''No Freedom Means Death'' in Korean. Hundreds of thousands of No
docs.lead_paragraph: A small number of North Korean refugees tried to hold a protest at the gates of the foreign ministry but were quickly detained by the police. Three people held up a small banner saying ''No Freedom Means Death'' in Korean. Hundreds of thousands of North Koreans live illegally in China, fleeing hunger and repression. While they wish to be considered political refugees protected by international treaties, China says they are economic migrants who should be sent home if caught. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

docs.abstract: Two teen-age boys convicted of arson in June fire that killed 25 in crowded Internet cafe, Beijing, are sentenced to life in prison; girl who helped them gets 12-year sentence (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Life Sentences For Internet Cafe Fire

docs.snippet: Two teen-age boys convicted of arson in a late-night fire that killed 25 in a crowded Internet cafe in June have been sentenced to life in prison. The boys, aided by a girl who received a 12-year sentence and a 13-year-old boy who was sent to juvenil
docs.lead_paragraph: Two teen-age boys convicted of arson in a late-night fire that killed 25 in a crowded Internet cafe in June have been sentenced to life in prison. The boys, aided by a girl who received a 12-year sentence and a 13-year-old boy who was sent to juvenile detention, reportedly set the deadly fire in anger after being denied admission to the cafe, in Beijing's university district. The cafe was a firetrap and the disaster led police to shut down many unlicensed Internet cafes. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

docs.abstract: Chinese police thwart effort of dozen North Korean refugees to enter Ecuadorean Embassy in Beijing in attempt to gain freedom and world's attention; most of North Koreans, including two teeange girls, are pushed to ground and dragged into waiting vans by police, who apparently anticipated attempt and had surrounded compound; some of North Koreans involved had provided prior statements to journalists saying their goal was political asylum in US: this is latest episode in escalating battle of wills involving North Koreans who are in China illegally and are trying to enter foreign embassies to gain asylum; photo (M)

headline.main: Chinese Police Thwart an Escape Attempt by North Koreans

docs.snippet: More than a dozen North Korean refugees rushed the fence of a heavily guarded compound of diplomatic buildings in central Beijing today in an attempt to gain freedom and the world's attention.     The police, apparently anticipating the attempt, had
docs.lead_paragraph: More than a dozen North Korean refugees rushed the fence of a heavily guarded compound of diplomatic buildings in central Beijing today in an attempt to gain freedom and the world's attention. The police, apparently anticipating the attempt, had surrounded the complex, and their response was swift and furious.

docs.abstract: About twenty North Koreans clamber over wall into German Embassy School in Beijing, evading Chinese police; photo; German ambassador persuades police not to enter compound; scene contrasts with mayhem day earlier when 12 North Koreans were dragged away from Ecuadorian Embassy (S)

headline.main: More Koreans Give China the Slip, Invading Embassy School

docs.snippet: About 20 North Koreans clambered over a low concrete wall and into the protection of the lightly guarded German Embassy School today, the second mass effort to gain asylum by North Koreans here in as many days.    The German ambassador rushed to the
docs.lead_paragraph: About 20 North Koreans clambered over a low concrete wall and into the protection of the lightly guarded German Embassy School today, the second mass effort to gain asylum by North Koreans here in as many days. The German ambassador rushed to the school and persuaded the Chinese police not to enter. Well into the night, the North Koreans, including at least one child, sat eating snacks on the wide stairs of a fire escape on the modern red building. Hordes of police officers paced outside.

docs.abstract: Chinese and German officials discuss what to do with group of North Korean asylum seekers who took refuge in German School, Beijing (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Talks On Asylum Seekers

docs.snippet: Chinese and German officials discussed what to do with a group of North Korean asylum seekers who took refuge in the German School in Beijing on Tuesday, German officials said. In the past, China has allowed North Koreans in the protection of foreign
docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese and German officials discussed what to do with a group of North Korean asylum seekers who took refuge in the German School in Beijing on Tuesday, German officials said. In the past, China has allowed North Koreans in the protection of foreign embassies to leave, ultimately for South Korea. There was no word from Chinese officials on another group of North Koreans arrested on Monday during an attempt to enter a diplomatic compound. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

docs.abstract: Air China is set to begin nonstop service between New York's Kennedy Airport and Beijing (S)

headline.main: Nonstop Flights Are Set From J.F.K. to Beijing

docs.snippet: In recent years, several airlines have been flying nonstop between New York and Hong Kong on polar routes, and this week Air China will begin nonstop service between New York and Beijing.    Polar routes, made possible with the opening of Russian air
docs.lead_paragraph: In recent years, several airlines have been flying nonstop between New York and Hong Kong on polar routes, and this week Air China will begin nonstop service between New York and Beijing. Polar routes, made possible with the opening of Russian air space in 1999 and a new generation of long-range jets, will reduce the travel time from New York to Beijing from about 20 hours to about 14 hours, partly by avoiding connections.

docs.abstract: Chinese government is rebuilding three-quarter-mile stretch of mighty wall, built mainly in latter half of Ming Dynasty from 1368 to 1643, that once formed protective ring around imperial capital and gave city its erstwhile romance but was demolished in 1950's and 1960's; is seeking to rebuild it with original bricks and has appealed to public to return any they may have taken when wall was torn down; quixotic, one-man crusade of 55-year-old factory worker Feng Baohua to locate and return bricks as public effort has languished; discussed; photos (M)

headline.main: Beijing Journal; Restoring an Ancient City's Glory Brick by Brick

docs.snippet: Prowl the back streets of central Beijing any evening and you may find a spry gray-haired man, dressed in sagging undershirt, shorts and sandals, rummaging through demolition sites.    Working in the hot-pink glow of smog-charged sunsets, Feng Baohua
docs.lead_paragraph: Prowl the back streets of central Beijing any evening and you may find a spry gray-haired man, dressed in sagging undershirt, shorts and sandals, rummaging through demolition sites. Working in the hot-pink glow of smog-charged sunsets, Feng Baohua mumbles with renewed pleasure every time he makes a find.

docs.abstract: Lodi Gyaltsen Gyari, envoy of Dalai Lama, expresses guarded optimism for new dialogue between Chinese government and exiled Tibetan spiritual leader after completing visit to Beijing, Shanghai and Tibet and meeting with several of region's top officials (M)

headline.main: Dalai Lama's Envoy Hopeful for China Talks

docs.snippet: An envoy of the Dalai Lama expressed guarded hopes over the weekend for a new dialogue between the Chinese government and the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader after completing a visit to Beijing, Shanghai and Tibet and meeting with several of the regi
docs.lead_paragraph: An envoy of the Dalai Lama expressed guarded hopes over the weekend for a new dialogue between the Chinese government and the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader after completing a visit to Beijing, Shanghai and Tibet and meeting with several of the region's top officials. ''We have made every effort to create the basis for opening a new chapter in our relationship,'' said the envoy, Lodi Gyaltsen Gyari, in a statement issued on Saturday by the Tibetan government in exile in India.
